Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a Synchronous Direct Digital Receiver System for Geospace Imaging Studies
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will build a facility for imaging high-energy electron precipitation and remote sensing high-energy particle dynamics in near-Earth space. They will design, test, and build a synchronous direct digital receiver that will form the foundation of the next-generation VLF-HF (Very Low Frequency/High Frequency) receivers/riometers. Using this technology and in collaboration with Canadian investigators, the researchers will deploy an array of these receivers to establish a comprehensive network of digital imaging riometers that will build international partnerships, take advantage of existing (and planned) networks of complementary instruments, and enable new and exciting science. The timely deployment of the riometer network will also be enhanced by synergies with space-based observations of the near-Earth geospace environment, such as NASA's Magnetospheric Multiscale (MMS) and Radiation Belt Storm Probes (RBSP) missions, as well as ESA's Swarm. The data and engineering study results from this effort will be made available to all researchers. All design documentation will be posted on the project website so that duplicate systems can be easily constructed. The engineering design work will be integrated into undergraduate curriculum, including independent studies and experimental courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The polar sky provides a window on the transfer of mass, energy, and momentum from the solar wind through geospace. Since the dawn of the space age, geospace has been studied for understanding (1) the functioning of planet Earth within the solar system, (2) numerous aspects of laboratory physics and astrophysics, and (3) the Sun’s influence on technological systems deployed on Earth and in space. The societal relevance of geospace is highlighted in the 2013-2022 NRC Decadal Strategy of Solar and Space Physics which emphasizes coordinated multipoint measurements in space and at many locations on Earth.

Early on, it was discovered that geospace sub-systems interact with each other, and that larger-scale processes are powered by solar radiation and the solar wind. Geospace dynamics and plasma physics are centrally important to space weather and its effects upon technologies which have societal and economic relevance. High latitudes are where geomagnetic field lines lie at the interface between the solar wind and the Earth’s magnetosphere – the magnetopause – that transfers solar wind energy into disturbances in the magnetosphere and ionosphere that can disturb and even disrupt technologies in space and on Earth’s surface. It is also the location that connects along magnetic field lines to geosynchronous orbit with its nearly 150 satellites and the location above which solar particles readily enter and, (i) through ionization effects produce GPS disruptions via scintillations and communication blackouts for polar-route aircraft, and (ii) high levels of particulate radiation at airline altitudes for passengers and crew. The advent in 1995 of the U.S. National Space Weather Program under the auspices of the Office of the Federal Coordinator for Meteorology provided the first opportunity for the coordination of research and applications across the seven government agencies that have important national interests in space weather. The Committee for Space Weather, co-chaired by individuals from NSF, NASA, NOAA, and the Air Force, is responsible for advancing the goals of the program.

 To further advance the understanding of Geospace, The Space Science Laboratory at Siena College designed, built and deployed a new radio receiving system to explore particle dynamics in near-Earth space.  The timely deployment of these systems will also be enhanced by synergies with space-based observations of the near-Earth geospace environment, such as NASA’s Magnetospheric Multiscale (MMS) and Radiation Belt Storm Probes (RBSP) missions, as well as ESA’s Swarm.

This work further addressed NSF's broader impact criteria in several ways. First, the data and engineering study results are available to all researchers and have the potential to enhance many other projects beyond those proposed herein. All design documentation (including, but not limited to: schematics, board layouts, base station software, FPGA code, and mechanical drawings) are posted on the project website.  This documentation will be of sufficient quality that a third party will be able to build a duplicate the system without consulting the Siena design team (though this team will be available if needed).  In addition, this site will host a discussion board and file repository allowing the community to suggest modifications to the experimental setup. Second, the engineering design work was integrated within many of Siena’s undergraduate curriculum, including independent studies, experimental courses. Finally, international relationships were continued with science teams from Canada and Denmark/Greenland.
